channel.title: Removing all word filtering and adding a word censor
channel.description:
[b]Description: [/b]How to do some modification to aString897 [b]Classes modified: [/b]client.java [b]Difficulty: [/b]1
Welcome to my shitty tutorial on making it so you can type like this (Got spazzed out) [img]http://img30.imageshack.us/img30/2446/clienttextshowoff.png[/img]
Or add a word censor. I believe it's been done before but I've never seen. My way takes little effort and uses the replace method.
My way removes all of the word filtering, meaning nothing you type will be changed when sent.
First off, you must comment out two lines. These lines are located in client.java and are what actually filters the text you send. [b]Note: Skip this part if you don't want to remove the text formatting.[/b]
Find [code]aString887 = Class35.method527(aString887, 0); aString887 = Class34.method497(aString887, 0);[/code]and comment it out (// before each line).
This part is where you add the censor. At the bottom of your client.java, declare a static string array called censorList. It should look like this. [code]public static string censorList[];[/code] Next, set its value to all of the words you want to filter out. If I wanted to filter out "fuck" like RuneScape does, I'd set it to something like this. [code]{"fuck","fuc","fuk","fk","fhk","fhc"}[/code]So overall, the code would look like this. [code]public static string filterList[] = {"fuck","shit","fuc","fuk","fk","fhk","fhc"};[/code]
Next we're going to actually filter the text sent.
Back under where you commented out the two lines, add this. [code] for(int number = 0; number < censorList.length; number++) { aString887 = aString887.replace(censorList[number], "****"); }[/code]Now I'll explain what each thing does.
The first line initiates the start of a for loop, which will make it loop through the censor list. The next line makes it check for and replace the censored word it's currently looking for. If it finds the censored word at any time, it will replace it with a ****. You can change this to whatever.
Also note that you can have multiple censor lists or make it so you don't have a list at all. If you decide to not have a censor list, you'll just do this. [code]aString887 = aString887.replace("word", "****");[/code]But you'll have to do it for each word. That's why I had you do it my way.
Anyway, thanks for viewing this. I was in the mood for some client hacking and wanted to remove the word filtering and actually learned a lot from messing with Class35.java, which is how I found this.
~Lin

item.dc:creator: @The_Flames The_Flames
item.description:
@The_Flames wrote:

You have to declare the string yourself.

Btw line, you should capitalise String in your tutorial (else it wont work).

item.title: Removing all word filtering and adding a word censor
item.dc:creator: @i_own_pking i_own_pking
item.description:
@i_own_pking wrote:

Sorry but this is not good.

The reason for the capitals is because your disabling the formatting, so if you put a full stop a capital will not appear after.

Also, if your going to use an array like that for the censor you might want to use aString897.toLowerCase() else you have to do every variation.

Read full topic
item.source: Removing all word filtering and adding a word censor

item.title: Removing all word filtering and adding a word censor
item.dc:creator: @runeite51 runeite51
item.description:
@runeite51 wrote:

EDIT: I just came to check to see if anyone replied, sorry I didn’t notice that the last post was on July 30.

one tiny problem I see capital letters, but other people on the server don’t…

EDIT: Still same problem above, (^^) but when I try and add censor so it does the right amount of stars, I have no idea where to put:

public String buildAsterisk(int length) { String s = ""; for(int i = 0; i < length; i++) { s += "*"; } return s; }

I tried server times but keep on getting an error, trying to fix the error and I get 100 errors. -;-
How do I add arrays or w/e i tried that and got errors too…

Just tell me what to copy and paste I’m just recovered from being sick (when you start to get the sore throat and stuffy ass nose), I can’t even think strait, so what do I copy and where do I paste. I just want it to say the right amount of stars…

Read full topic

item.title: Removing all word filtering and adding a word censor
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“SonGoku, post:6, topic:280139”]Or:

public String buildAsterisk(int length) { String s = ""; for(int i = 0; i < length; i++) { s += "*"; } return s; } [/quote]That’s one way, but I’d prefer to do it the array way. It’s not good to put loops within loops, especially for something so small.

Read full topic
item.source: Removing all word filtering and adding a word censor

item.title: Removing all word filtering and adding a word censor
item.dc:creator: @SonGoku SonGoku
item.description:
@SonGoku wrote:

Or:

	public String buildAsterisk(int length) {
		String s = "";
		for(int i = 0; i < length; i++) {
			s += "*";
		}
		return s;
	}

Read full topic
item.source: Removing all word filtering and adding a word censor

item.title: Removing all word filtering and adding a word censor
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“primadude, post:4, topic:280139”]By the way, with your method of censoring, will it always censor with four stars no matter how many characters the censored word contains? If it does I can help you with that.[/quote]Indeed it does. I already know how to fix that. One way it create an array and set around 10 values each asterisk count (*, **, ***, etc) and make it choose the one that’s the length of the word. Another way is doing some shitty math

Read full topic

item.title: Removing all word filtering and adding a word censor
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Description: How to do some modification to aString897
Classes modified: client.java
Difficulty: 1

Welcome to my shitty tutorial on making it so you can type like this (Got spazzed out)

Or add a word censor. I believe it’s been done before but I’ve never seen. My way takes little effort and uses the replace method.

My way removes all of the word filtering, meaning nothing you type will be changed when sent.

First off, you must comment out two lines. These lines are located in client.java and are what actually filters the text you send.
Note: Skip this part if you don’t want to remove the text formatting.

Find

aString887 = Class35.method527(aString887, 0); aString887 = Class34.method497(aString887, 0);and comment it out (// before each line).

This part is where you add the censor. At the bottom of your client.java, declare a static string array called censorList. It should look like this.

public static string censorList[];

Next, set its value to all of the words you want to filter out. If I wanted to filter out “fuck” like RuneScape does, I’d set it to something like this.

{"fuck","fuc","fuk","fk","fhk","fhc"}So overall, the code would look like this.

public static string filterList[] = {"fuck","shit","fuc","fuk","fk","fhk","fhc"};

Next we’re going to actually filter the text sent.

Back under where you commented out the two lines, add this.

for(int number = 0; number < censorList.length; number++) { aString887 = aString887.replace(censorList[number], "****"); }Now I’ll explain what each thing does.

The first line initiates the start of a for loop, which will make it loop through the censor list. The next line makes it check for and replace the censored word it’s currently looking for. If it finds the censored word at any time, it will replace it with a ****. You can change this to whatever.

Also note that you can have multiple censor lists or make it so you don’t have a list at all. If you decide to not have a censor list, you’ll just do this.

aString887 = aString887.replace("word", "****");But you’ll have to do it for each word. That’s why I had you do it my way.

Anyway, thanks for viewing this. I was in the mood for some client hacking and wanted to remove the word filtering and actually learned a lot from messing with Class35.java, which is how I found this.

~Lin
